title: 'Apathetic' home loan customers to blame for 'loyalty tax'
text:
He said prudential regulators’ rules had been principal-based, rather than “highly prescriptive”. Banks can be “highly prescriptive”, he said, adding that the banks would be likely to say the same about the regulators.

“There is a lack of common sense by banks in their application of ‘responsible lending rules,” he added.

Separately, borrowers and mortgage brokers regularly complain that forensic analysis of applicants’ spending and income had delayed loan applications.

Mr Samuel also said an online calculator recommended by the Productivity Commission will allow consumers to compare home loan rates. APRA, ASIC and Treasury in are discussions to try and have it up and running by next year.

Existing comparison site providers claim they offer more than 7000 variations on hundreds of mortgages, compared to about 4000 mortgages and comparison being proposed by the regulators’ scheme.

Mr Samuel said it was important to ensure there was no repeat of the problem that hit iSelect, which was criticised by the Australian Consumer and Competition Commission for failing to disclose that it featured recommendations based upon business relationships.

Mr Samuel is a former chairman of the ACCC.

Comparison websites earn income from research, commission for directing borrowers to lender and advertising.

Advertisement

But major website chiefs deny their recommendations are influenced by remuneration.

Steve Mickenbecker, group executive for Canstar, said it offers 4000 home loans from 113 lenders.

“We rate on value comparing the price and features of products and services to determine what represents overall value for consumers not just the cheapest option.

"We go to great lengths to carefully avoid any potential conflicts of interest between our commercial and research divisions,” Mr Mickenbecker said.

Finder’s co-founder and director Frank Restuccia said: “We recognise that sometimes too much choice can lead to decision paralysis, so we curate leading offers in each category to help Australians make better decisions.”

He added: “We’re constantly reviewing the site to make sure we’re offering a great service and as rates and offers shift, we update our site accordingly.”

Paul Marshall, chief executive of RateCity, said he was “not confident” an official comparison website could do any better.
description: Graeme Samuel has blamed problems with  mortgage competition on a combination of borrowers’ “inertia and apathy" and said websites comparing home loan rates were freely available.
